resources.string: Before you start step 1, please see Rubik\'s Cube notation. Below pictures should make everything clear. The rule with the marking is: if you look on cube from the front, turn once by 90 degrees clockwise, is marked with the letter F. Countermovement (counterclockwise) marked with F \'. And the same rule applies to all other walls (e.g. the up wall: U / U \'- up, down wall: D / D\' -down etc.).

I think if you want to set a whole Rubik’s cube, you should be able to complete first wall without any guidance. This is quite intuitive. When done, please turn the middle ring so that you get a \"T\" on cube (as below picture shows in initial situation).

In step 1, we complete second ring with using below shown algorithm. In example from the picture, you put a red-white stone in the right place (of course you can start with every stone, it does not have to be red-white). To find correct stones, please turn lower ring with D / D \' movement. If there is no stone in right position to insert (and the second level is not completed), it means that a stone is somewhere in second ring but in wrong position. In this case, use the same algorithm to \"throw\" this wrong stone out from the second ring to the lower ring. Then put the stone in the right position to perform algorithm again. Repeat this process until the entire second ring is completed. Then you can continue with step 2.

Above algorithm inserts stones to the right and so is sufficient to complete this step. But can be easier and quicker if you know algorithm to move blocks in other direction (to the left), as shown in the picture below.

In the second step we will put a cross on the top face. First turn the cube so that incomplete (bottom) face is on the top - as in the picture above in \"initial situation\". \"Initial situation\" shows a case when no element of the cross is finished. In this case, we will execute following algorithm once or twice.
As a result, you should get \"L\" letter, which should look as in the picture below. Then you execute the algorithm again to get a finished cross.

If something is not clear, look at the picture below to see what happens after each execution of the algorithm on the cube (the worst situation is indicated when the algorithm has to be performed three times to get the final effect). Please remember to adjust the cube accordingly if you already have the letter \"L\", as in the picture above!
After making cross on the top, you need to put in this step edge pieces on their final places to match colors of side center pieces.

The following algorithm can exchange two pieces in neighboring walls. Depending on the situation in the cube, you may need to run this algorithm multiple times. As a result, you should get the entire cross with matching sidewalls.

If something is not clear, please look at the picture below. It shows the worst situation when the algorithm has to be executed 3 times, in order to put all cross elements in right places. Please don’t forget to keep cube in right position when doing algorithm (as shown in the picture with \"eye\" above).

Congratulations ! Come here means, you are very close to finish the entire cube. Fourth algorithm places top-level corners in right positions. For the moment, corners do not have to match corresponding colors on side walls. It is important that they are only in correct positions (eg cornerstone at the intersection of the walls: red-yellow-blue should consist of colors: red-yellow-blue, etc.).
If none of corner pieces are in the right place, run following algorithm. As a result, at least one corner piece should come in the right position.

Now find out which corner piece is in correct position and place the cube in such way that when looking from the front, already set corner piece is in the top left corner of the cube (as in the picture below). Then, depending on the other corners, execute the algorithm again once or twice until all corners are in proper positions.

If something is not clear, please look at the picture below, where shown what happened on the cube after each execution of the algorithm (example shows case when algorithm has to be executed twice to get final effect of step 4). Please remember always set the cube so that the corner piece, you DO NOT want to move, is in the upper left corner of the cube !!
If something does not work, do not give up and try again. This step is the hardest part of setting the cube. But the last, fifth algorithm is very simple!
In the last step, you will finally orient corner pieces (that means, turn corner pieces to match wall colors - see picture below).
Now please do simple algorithm from the below picture 2 or 4 times - until the transformed corner piece is correctly oriented.
Now rotate the upper ring in U\' direction until the next incorrectly oriented corner piece is in position to perform algorithm again 2 or 4 times.
Repeat this process for improperly oriented corner pieces until the cube is completed!
During these steps, the cube looks like it\'s all mixed up. Do not worry - it should be like this! Everything comes back to its positions :)))

But if this is not completely clear for you, look at the picture below which shows an example where all four corners have to be rotate. \"OK\" marks corners which have already been arranged after applying the algorithm. Note that in the meantime the cube actually looks confused ... but in the end everything returns to its places!
